pullRequest.body:
This PR is centered around the (generalized) elliptic relations (`relâ‚„`)
$E(a,b,c,d): W_{a+b}W_{a-b}W_{c+d}W_{c-d}=W_{a+c}W_{a-c}W_{b+d}W_{b-d}-W_{a+d}W_{a-d}W_{b+c}W_{b-c}$.
For an integer-indexed sequence W valued in a commutative ring, the relation makes sense only when a,b,c,d are all integers or all half integers. For convenience of formalization, we instead consider integers a,b,c,d of the same parity and divide all subscripts by 2. We extract the subexpression $W_{(a+b)/2}W_{(a-b)/2}$ (which appear six times) as `addMulSub W a b`.

The collection of all $E(a,b,c,d)$ is equivalent to Stange's axiom for elliptic nets (`net`), and the literature (e.g. Silverman) commonly consider only the three-index special case $E(m,n,r,0)$ (`Relâ‚ƒ`). Important special cases of these relations are
(i) $E(m+1,m,1,0): W_{2m+1}W_1^3=W_{m+2}W_m^3-W_{m+1}^3 W_{m-1}$ (`oddRec`) and
(ii) $E(m+1,m-1,1,0): W_{2m}W_2 W_1^2=W_m(W_{m+2}W_{m-1}^2-W_{m-2}W_{m+1}^2)$ (`evenRec`), 
which suffice to uniquely specify $W$ on all positive integers recursively from four initial values $W_1, W_2, W_3, W_4$ (`IsEllSequence.ext`, if $W_1 W_2$ is not a zero divisor). In the usual setting where $W_1=1$ and $W_2\mid W_4$, there does exist a sequence (`normEDS`) satisfying (i) and (ii) given initial values $W_2, W_3$ and $W_4/W_2$. It turns out the same non-zerodivisor condition also guarantees that W is an odd function with $W_0=0$, which naturally extends W to all integers.

The main result of this PR (`relâ‚„_of_oddRec_evenRec`, `IsEllSequence.of_oddRec_evenRec`) is a purely algebraic proof that the sequence W defined by the single-parameter elliptic relations (i) and (ii) implies all $E(a,b,c,d)$, based on my original argument first published on [Math.SE](https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4903422/12932). It's based on the observation that a nonzerodivisor-multiple of $E(a,b,c,d)$ can be expressed as a linear combination of various $E(a,b,c_\min,d_\min)$ with the two smallest indices fixed at their minimal possible values, which can be transformed (`transf`) to an elliptic relation with smaller `a` (which can be assumed to hold by induction), unless they are of the form (i) or (ii) which hold by assumption. For this argument it's necessary to assume `a > b > c > d â‰¥ 0` (see `StrictAntiâ‚„` and `Relâ‚„OfValid`), but it's easy to extend to arbitrary a,b,c,d by symmetry properties of `relâ‚„` under negation and permutations of indices.

In the subsequent PR #13057, we show all normalized EDSs (`normEDS`), defined using the even-odd recursion (i)-(ii), are elliptic (i.e. satisfy the elliptic relations) divisibility sequences. This PR doesn't directly apply because a normEDS doesn't always satisfy the nonzerodivisor condition, but they are specializations of the universal normEDS, which does satisfy the condition. The technique of reducing to the universal case will be applied many times, and relies on  the naturality (`map`) lemmas.

We also change the `â„•` in the definition `IsDivSequence` to `â„¤` which is more natural given that W is a `â„¤`-indexed sequence.

---

- [x] depends on: #13153

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

-->

#### Import changes

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.NumberTheory.EllipticDivisibilitySequence | 527 | 822 | +295 (+55.98%) |

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ EvenRec`
`+ HaveSameParityâ‚„`
`+ IsDivSequence.map`
`+ IsEllDivSequence.map`
`+ IsEllSequence.map`
`+ OddRec`
`+ Relâ‚ƒ`
`+ StrictAntiâ‚„`

`+ _root_.IsEllSequence.of_oddRec_evenRec`

`+ avgâ‚„_add_avgâ‚„`
`+ cMin`
`+ dMin`
`+ dMin_le`
`+ dMin_lt_cMin`
`+ dMin_nonneg`
`+ evenRec`

`+ invarNum_mul_invarDenom_of_net`

`+ negOnePow_dMin`

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

</details>
Requesting a review from @Multramate since you're probably the only one who've read my proof on StackExchange :)
Hi @Multramate do you have plans to review this in the near future? If there's any difficulty please let me know.
I'll give a brief review today. I won't have much time this week and next week, but I'll do the full review after that.

@alreadydone Coming here for PR triage, it seems this PR is waiting for you to respond to the review comments. (You also have a merge conflict.) I have thus labelled it awaiting-author. Please remove this label when this is ready for review again. Thanks!

Here are some very preliminary comments on the naming mostly on the first half of the PR, without looking at the code or referring to your notes. I still think that this is a massive PR, especially since your argument is new. There isn't an obvious structure to the lemmas even if I understood the entire argument, and many definitions seem to just be auxiliary to prove some small part of the argument. I reckon will take very a long time to review, so I still suggest that you find a way to split this further.
Thanks, pushed some initial fixes.

Here are some further preliminary comments. Now that I've some time to try to understand the code organisation, I feel that we should extract out all the stuff not directly necessary in the proof of the main result (i.e. the stuff on `net` and `invarNum/Denom`).
These are a massive number of imports. Can these be squeezed into fewer?
Squeezing is already automated by `lake exe shake` (already a step in CI).

I feel that the stuff on elliptic nets may deserve its own file, maybe `EllipticNet.lean`, or we can make `EllipticDivisibilitySequence` a folder and split this file into two subfiles. In any case, I think you should elaborate this in detail in the module docstrings, and do add a reference to Stange's paper or otherwise.

I think splitting this to another file would break the coherence and the flow of this file, since `net` is closely connected (equivalent) to `relâ‚„`. I would only consider splitting if we want to define `net` more generally on arbitrary abelian groups instead of â„¤.

I agree I should mention it in module docstring and add the reference.

We should still have a reference on your entire MSE argument *somewhere*. I would personally just write it all out in the module docstrings, but you can also just add a link to the MSE answer. Once you've incorporated it to the notes (or write a paper containing the argument), you should link that instead.

On the stuff on elliptic nets: it seems that you don't actually use `net`s in the proof of `_root_.IsEllSequence.of_oddRec_evenRec`, which was supposed to be the main theorem in this PR? I suggest omitting these entirely in this PR.

If you were to define `net`, you should split it eventually into its own file, partly to set up a precedent to develop the general theory over abelian groups, and partly because it's going to be very long once we add the code from the other PRs.

I'm not a huge fan of the subscript naming, unless it's something like $\psi_2$ where we're defining a sequence. This could instead be some mixture of the keywords `addMulSub`, `mul`, `add`, `sub`, `cyclic`, `partition`, etc.

The subscript means the number of arguments, and I'm using this convention consistently in this file. It's not uncommon to use subscripts to indicate the number of arguments involved, see e.g. [congr_funâ‚ƒ](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Batteries/Logic.html#congr_fun%E2%82%83) and [norm_addâ‚ƒ_le](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/Basic.html#norm_add%E2%82%83_le).

This is a term (unlike Relâ‚ƒ, which is a Prop), but I use the same name (just different capitalization) because its close connection to Relâ‚ƒ.

Again note that this is defined in terms of `addMulSub` and both are auxiliary to the proof so we shouldn't care much about the name. It's equivalent to `net` but `net` is easier to use. (We could consider making both private, but then you won't see them in the online docs. Maybe it doesn't matter because if anyone wants to understand the proof they would need to look at the source code anyway.)
This name doesn't reflect the `div 2`, but I can't think of a better name.

I can add a subscript 2 but this def is auxiliary to the proof and not expected to be used outside of this file, so I don't care much about its name ... It's also an implementation detail, it's inconvenient to make a type for $\frac12\mathbb{Z}$ in Lean so we use $\mathbb{Z}$ instead, and that's why we need to divide by 2.
Ditto, and note that this is a relation (so `Rel` still makes sense), but `relâ‚„` is an element of `R` so it should be called something else.
See above; I want to keep the name of `relâ‚„` to stress close connection with `Relâ‚ƒ` (see `relâ‚ƒ_iffâ‚„`), but I should probably make `relâ‚„` private.

Here is my suggestion: make this into an term `relâ‚ƒ` of `R` rather than a `Prop`, and replace instances of `Relâ‚ƒ` elsewhere with `relâ‚ƒ .. = 0`. I prefer keeping this analogous to `relâ‚„` (especially if you decide to expose it, but also for people who might read the source code), and lemmas like `relâ‚ƒ_iff_relâ‚„_eq_zero` suggest that `relâ‚ƒ` and `relâ‚„` are terms of the same type. In any case, `W (m + n) * W (m - n) * W r ^ 2 - W (m + r) * W (m - r) * W n ^ 2 + W (n + r) * W (n - r) * W m ^ 2 = 0` might be more suggestive of its cyclic nature.

I still don't quite like `rel` because that suggests a `Prop`, but I guess it's a "relator" rather than a "relation".
Can we avoid using `ring_nf`? Can we put `invarNum` and `invarDenom` into the `simp_rw` in `norm`?

`norm := (simp_rw [invarNum, invarDenom, net]; ring_nf)` works, but if I replace `ring_nf` by `ring` Lean will tell me to use `ring_nf`. I think it's because `ring` doesn't only work in the ring `R` but also in the ring `â„¤` to normalize the arguments of `W`. Maybe Lean shouldn't complain and this behavior should be reported as a bug?
`addMulSub_neg_left/right`?
Ditto
`addMulSub_self`?
Can we avoid `ring_nf`? Also put `conv_rhs` on the next line?
Ditto; there's no easy way to avoid it. Is there a reason that you want to avoid `ring_nf`?
`characteristic` typo

Saying it's an invariant doesn't really explain why we care about this quantity, I suggest putting an explanation in the module docstring and then only referring to that here. Note that `invarDenom` hasn't been defined at this point.

`invarDenom` is defined right after this, so I think it's reasonable to mention them together in this docstring. I'm not sure what to put in the module docstring, and how are you going to "referring to that here"? I think from purely the viewpoint of an EDS, this is interesting for the sake it being an invariant. We can mention that it plays a role in the theory of division polynomials (in the definition of $\omega_n$), and is actually (congruent to) a univariate polynomial there.

I haven't read through your notes, but from the MSE answer and the main comment in this PR, these are unrelated to `_root_.IsEllSequence.of_oddRec_evenRec`, which was supposed to be the main theorem in this PR?
Can we avoid `ring_nf`?
Can we avoid `ring_nf`?
Can we avoid `ring_nf`?
Can we avoid `ring_nf`?
Can we avoid `ring_nf`?
`invarNum_mul_invarDenom`?
`invarNum_mul_invarDenom_of_net`? Or some version with `comm`?
changed to `invarNum_mul_invarDenom_of_net`.
I would do `relâ‚ƒ_iff_relâ‚„_eq_zero` instead, but again I'm not a fan of the subscripts
Changed to relâ‚ƒ_iff_relâ‚„_eq_zero
`IsStrictAntiLT`? Is `Anti` a common keyword?

[StrictAnti](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Monotone/Basic.html#StrictAnti) is a thing (a Prop). StrictAnti is about LT and Anti is about LE. I should probably make this private as well ...
Spell out `average`?
I don't want to make it longer because it appears a lot of times. I can make it private though.
Again, this is an element so why is it a `rel`?
See above; it's named because of close connection with `relâ‚„`.
`relâ‚„Fin4`?
I feel like `transf` really doesn't justify what these lemmas are doing.

I added this docstring to explain what the transformation is:
```
/-! Preservation of `relâ‚„`, `HaveSameParityâ‚„`, and `strictAntiâ‚„` under the transformation
  `(a,b,c,d) â†¦ (avgâ‚„ a b c d - d, avgâ‚„ a b c d - c, avgâ‚„ a b c d - b, |avgâ‚„ a b c d - a|)`. -/
```

I think these will end up in the same line, so maybe you want to do:
```suggestion
 * M. Ward, *Memoir on Elliptic Divisibility Sequences*
 * [K Stange, *Elliptic nets and elliptic curves*][Stange2011]
```
I was told to indent them by one space to make formatting work properly.

While you're at this, can you add the proper reference to Ward's article in the mathlib bibliography (and remove the `.` in `M.` to make it consistent)?

I guess if we were to make this private, we won't need the docstring, so maybe make these `/- -/` instead?

Do you think it's better if we make literally everything except `_root_.IsEllSequence.of_oddRec_evenRec` (including `cMin` and `dMin`) private? If everything were to be private, I guess I don't care about the code...

I don't actually know how I feel about making this (and `relâ‚„`, etc) private. On one hand it's an implementation detail, but on the other hand the facts about `relâ‚„` are fine results on their own that are highly symmetric.
If we hide `relâ‚„`, then we can't talk about it here.
What is the recommended symbol to use here? I always used `=>` but you always use `â†¦`.

Seems like these and everything below are unrelated to `_root_.IsEllSequence.of_oddRec_evenRec`, but instead a consequence of `relâ‚„_of_oddRec_evenRec` and the lemmas for `invarNum/Denom`, and only added here because it's part of a downstream PR. I hope this is not too much work, but given the size of the PR (and the novelty of the argument), I suggest that you split off everything that's not directly related to the main argument.
You should certainly add your name here.

My opinion on `ring_nf` is that it should never be used in the final code. Instead it's just a way to understand the expressions on both sides while proving a result, to be replaced with `ring` at the end (I prefer `ring1` because it would fail if both sides are not identical). It might be only my side but I also feel that `ring_nf` is significantly slower than `ring1` when compiling. Its behaviour should (heuristically) be identical to `ring1`, otherwise it's a bug...

pullRequest.title: feat(NumberTheory/EllipticDivisibilitySequence): show elliptic relations follow from even-odd recursion

source.title: feat(EllipticCurve): ZSMul formula in terms of division polynomials

Here are some very preliminary comments on the naming mostly on the first half of the PR, without looking at the code or referring to your notes. I still think that this is a massive PR, especially since your argument is new.
